Yes but you also agree to the terms of service when you want to play. You break that agreement and you get ban. It would be like getting an apartment and breaking the rules which leads to you being kicked out. The landlord (Or whom ever own that place to begin with) has no right to give you all that money back or any improvements you made to the house (wallpaper, carpeting, wiring, etc) because you did that in your own accord.

If you read the terms of service you basically don't own the account. Yes you make one, but it's not yours to begin with. We are in a sense borrowing it, as well as we give them money when we put it into the account. It's the same reason why we never really buy the items like skins, boost, champions, icons, etc. we buy the RP. Plus this is basically how it is for any type of digital service. People make it seem like Riot is the only company to do this!

If you used PayPal and the charges are less than 6 months old, dispute them and get your money back.  Otherwise, take them to small claims court if you have the wherewithal.  They won't be able to defend themselves without hiring a lawyer, or flying a retained one out to your local court, and that would cost them much more than the $300 you might ask for.  Or in other words, they can't defend themselves...and the EULA counts as so much toilet paper in a court of law.

This is the only reason why they get away with this treatment of players : because they haven't been pushed back, yet.  Steam used to have no return policy.  Then they started getting hit with suits.  Now they have a return policy.  It's the way of the world, sadly.  You won't get proper treatment unless / until you fight for it.
Except that RIOT will win because the EULA is a legally binding document between a user and RIOT and then RIOT will countersue for their legal fees.
EULAs aren't legally binding, at least not in the United States.  And Riot can countersue for their legal fees all they like.  Given the size of their company, judges aren't going to award them.
